case_name: Burmah Shell Oil Storage Distributing Company of India Ltd. v. Belgaum Borough Municipality

facts.text: Civil Appeal No 431/1961 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated May 31, 1960, of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 94 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No 431/1961. Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 31, 1960, of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 94 of 1959.

facts.text: Burmah Shell Oil Storage Distributing Company of India Ltd. is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: the Burmah Shell Oil Storage Distributing Company of India Ltd. is the appellant and the Belgaum Borough Municipality, Belguam, the respondent.

facts.text: Belgaum Borough Municipality is the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: the Burmah Shell Oil Storage Distributing Company of India Ltd. is the appellant and the Belgaum Borough Municipality, Belguam, the respondent.

facts.text: Appeal granted by certificate under Article 133(1)(b) of the Constitution by Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by certificate ,under Article 133  1   b  of the Constitution granted by the High Court of Mysore against its judgment and order dated May 31, 1960,

facts.text: Company filed writ petition under Article 226 against Municipality to prohibit levy of octroi on products brought inside octroi limits for sale.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal arises out of proceedings companysenced by the Company against the Municipality under Article 226 of the-constitution for a writ or, writs to prohibit the Municipality from arguing octroi from the Company on its products brought inside the octroi limits for sale.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The petition of the companypany was dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: Company manufactures petrol and petroleum products in refineries outside octroi limits of Belgaum Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: The Company deals in petrol and other petroleum products which it manufactures in its refineries situated outside the octroi limits of Belgaum Municipality It brings these products inside the said area either for use or companysumption by itself or for sale generally to its dealers and licensees

facts.text: Company brings products inside Belgaum octroi limits for its own use or consumption or for sale to dealers and licensees.

anchor.surface_text: The Company deals in petrol and other petroleum products which it manufactures in its refineries situated outside the octroi limits of Belgaum Municipality It brings these products inside the said area either for use or companysumption by itself or for sale generally to its dealers and licensees who in their turn sell them to others.

facts.text: Company directly sells products to Government (Civil and Military), local bodies, and big private concerns.

anchor.surface_text: The Company also directly sells its products to Government both Civil Military, and to local bodies and big private companycerns.

facts.text: Company has Divisional Office and Depot in Belgaum.

anchor.surface_text: The Company has a Divisional Office and Depot in Belgaum and the petition in the High Court was filed ,by the Divisional Manager in- charge of that area.

facts.text: Goods brought by Company divided into four categories: 1. Consumed by Company; 2. Sold and consumed within limits by others; 3. Sold within but consumed outside; 4. Sent from depot to extra-municipal points.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Company, the goods, brought by it within the octroi limits can be divided into four separate categories as follows 1 . Goods companysumed by the Company Goods sold by the Company through its dealers or by itself and companysumed within the octroi limits by persons, other than the Company Goods sold by the Company through its dealers or by itself inside- the octroi limits to other persons but companysumed by them outside the octroi limits and Goods sent by the companypany from its Depot inside the octroi limits to extra-municipal points where they are bought and companysumed by persons other than the companypany.

facts.text: Octroi duty levied for period October 22, 1955 to October 22, 1958 amounted to Rs. 1,40,544.51 nP on all goods irrespective of categories.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in this appeal with a period of three years companymencing on October 22, 1955, and ending on a like date in 1958. During this time, octroi duty levied on all goods brought inside the octroi limits of the Municipality, irrespective of their destination according to the four categories above enumerated, amounted to Rs. 1,40,544.51 nP.

facts.text: Company claimed not liable to pay octroi on categories other than the first.

anchor.surface_text: The Company claimed in the High Court that it was number liable to pay octroi on categories other than the first. This claim was rejected but the Municipality agreed to give a refund according to rules- in respect of the fourth category.

facts.text: High Court rejected Company's claim but Municipality agreed to refund for fourth category.

anchor.surface_text: The Company claimed in the High Court that it was number liable to pay octroi on categories other than the first. This claim was rejected but the Municipality agreed to give a refund according to rules- in respect of the fourth category.

facts.text: Belgaum Municipality governed by Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with the companytentions in the case it is necessary to refer briefly to the scheme of taxation under the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925, by which the Belgaum Municipality is governed

facts.text: Section 73(iv) of the Act empowers Municipality to impose octroi on animals or goods brought within octroi limits for consumption, use or sale therein.

anchor.surface_text: iv an octroi on animals or goods or both, brought within the octroi limits for company- sumption, use or sale therein The words -use or sale were substituted for the words or use from May 5, 1954, by an Amending Act of 1954  Bombay Act 35 of 1954 .

facts.text: Words 'use or sale' substituted for 'or use' in Section 73(iv) from May 5, 1954 by Bombay Act 35 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The words -use or sale were substituted for the words or use from May 5, 1954, by an Amending Act of 1954  Bombay Act 35 of 1954 . In other words, before 1954 the word sale did number figure in the description of octroi

facts.text: After 1954 amendment, rules and by-laws were not reframed nor procedure under sections 75, 76 followed for imposing octroi on goods for sale.

anchor.surface_text: When the Act was amended in 1954 by including the word sale in the description of octroi the rules and by-laws were number reframed number was the procedure under section 76 read with section 58 followed to impose octroi on animals and goods sold within the octroi limits.

facts.text: Company contended that since procedure not followed after amendment, octroi cannot be collected on goods merely sold but not consumed inside limits.

anchor.surface_text: The Company which had paid octroi on all its products brought within the octroi limits of the Belgaum Municipality. before the amendment including , the goods number companysumed by itself but sold to others started a companyrespondence saying that in as much as the law was newly amended to include sale in the description of octroi, the Rules and By-laws ought to have been framed again and the procedure under section 76 read, with section 58  j  followed.

facts.text: Municipality agreed to refund octroi on goods sent outside limits (fourth category) subject to rules.

anchor.surface_text: Even before the High Court the learned Advocate appearing for the Municipality stated that if any goods belonging to the companypany were actually sent outside the octroi limits the Municipality was prepared to grant refund on proof thereof, That is the stand of the Municipality even to-day.

facts.text: Company admitted liable to pay octroi on goods consumed by itself (first category).

anchor.surface_text: The Company also stated before us that it was liable to pay octroi on goods companysumed by itself. The dis- pute has thus narrowed down to the second and third categories.

facts.text: Dispute narrowed to second and third categories of goods.

anchor.surface_text: The Company also stated before us that it was liable to pay octroi on goods companysumed by itself. The dis- pute has thus narrowed down to the second and third categories.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Company liable to pay octroi on second and third categories.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the companypany was liable to pay octroi tax on goods brought into local area,  a  to be companysumed by itself or sold by it to companysumers direct and  b  for sale to dealers who in their turn sold the goods to companysumers within the municipal area irrespective of whether such companysumers bought them for use in the area or outside it.

facts.text: Company not liable for goods re-exported (fourth category) but must follow refund procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany was, however, number liable to octroi in respect of goods which it brought into the local area and which were re-exported. But to enable the companypany to save itself from tax in that case it had to follow the procedure laid down by rules for refund of taxes.

facts.text: Appeal fails.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons above stated this appeal must fail.

section 73. That section provides inter alia as follows - Subject to any general or special orders which the State Government may make in this behalf and to the provisions of section 75 and 76 a Municipality may impose for the purposes of this Act any of the following taxes, namely x x x x  iv an octroi on animals or goods or both, brought within the octroi limits for company- sumption, use or sale therein

anchor.surface_text: Before the amendment of the Boroughs Act in 1954, rule 4 1  of the Octroi Rules and By-laws ran as follows-- Subject to the exemptions and the provisions hereinafter expressly specified, a tax on all goods of the description mentioned in Schedule A hereto annexed, shall, on the import there. of, be payable to the Municipality

concepts.interpretation: Continued post-amendment without change; levy on import of scheduled goods

issues.text: Whether the inclusion of the word 'sale' in the description of octroi under section 73(iv) by the 1954 amendment required the Municipality to reframe rules and follow the procedure under sections 76 read with 58(j), 75, 77 and 60 as for a new tax

anchor.surface_text: The Company which had paid octroi on all its products brought within the octroi limits of the Belgaum Municipality. before the amendment including , the goods not consumed by itself but sold to others started a correspondence saying that in as much as the law was newly amended to include sale in the description of octroi, the Rules and By-laws ought to have been framed again and the procedure under section 76 read, with section 58 j followed. As this was not done, the Company contended, the tax could not be collected on goods which were merely sold but not consumed inside-the octroi limits.

issues.text: Whether prior to the 1954 amendment, octroi under section 73(iv) was payable only where goods were brought for consumption or use by the importer himself and not where brought for sale to others even if for their consumption or use therein

anchor.surface_text: The dispute has thus narrowed down to the second and third categories. The learned Attorney General appearing for the Company contends that the words consumption or use must be contrasted with the word sale. Sale, he argues, introduces a person other than the one who brings the goods or animals within the Municipal limit and as the words consumption or use are not qualified to say that the consumption or use may be by any one, those words must necessarily denote consumption or use by the, very person who brings the goods or animals.

issues.text: Whether octroi is payable on goods sold by the Company inside the octroi limits to persons who consume them outside the limits (third category)

anchor.surface_text: According to the Company, the goods, brought by it within the octroi limits can be divided into four separate categories as follows 1 . Goods consumed by the Company Goods sold by the Company through its dealers or by itself and consumed within the octroi limits by persons, other than the Company Goods sold by the Company through its dealers or by itself inside- the octroi limits to other persons but consumed by them outside the octroi limits and Goods sent by the companypany from its Depot inside the octroi limits to extra-municipal points where they are bought and consumed by persons other than the companypany.

arguments.claim: Rules and by-laws ought to have been reframed and procedure under section 76 read with section 58(j) followed after 1954 amendment adding 'sale', otherwise tax cannot be collected on goods merely sold but not consumed inside octroi limits

anchor.surface_text: The Company which had paid octroi on all its products brought within the octroi limits of the Belgaum Municipality. before the amendment including , the goods not consumed by itself but sold to others started a correspondence saying that in as much as the law was newly amended to include sale in the description of octroi, the Rules and By-laws ought to have been framed again and the procedure under section 76 read, with section 58  j  followed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: anysumption by buyers inside the area. In this sense the amplification of the description both in the Government of India Act 1935 and the Constitutio

arguments.court_reasoning: The tax still remained the same. Its nature, incidence or rate were not altered.

arguments.claim: Words 'consumption or use' must be contrasted with 'sale'; they denote consumption or use by the very person who brings the goods or animals, not by others

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney General appearing for the Company contends that the words consumption or use must be contrasted with the word sale. Sale, he argues, introduces a person other than the one who brings the goods or animals within the Municipal limit and as the words consumption or use are not qualified to say that the consumption or use may be by any one, those words must necessarily denote consumption or use by the, very person who brings the goods or animals.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ce number merely to the individual importer or purchaser but as companytemplating distribution eventually to companysumers in general within the State

arguments.court_reasoning: Expression 'for the purpose of consumption' contemplates distribution to consumers in general within the area; not limited to importer.

arguments.claim: Post-1954 amendment amounts to new tax requiring procedure under sections 75, 76, 77 and 60

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded that after the amendment the tax was intended to be collected even in respect of goods brought for sale but here it is pointed out that the procedure under sections 75, 76 and 77 has not been followed as required by section 60 of the Boroughs Act and the imposition of octroi on goods and animals brought in, for sale fails to be effective.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: anysumption by buyers inside the area. In this sense the amplification of the description both in the Government of India Act 1935 and the Constitutio

arguments.court_reasoning: No new tax; amendment did not alter nature of existing tax.

arguments.claim: Burmah Shell Oil Storage and Dist. Co. v. Manmad Municipality supports that new procedure required for new tax post-amendment

anchor.surface_text: It is said that this amounts to a new tax and it needed to be imposed according to the provisions above- mentioned and reliance is placed ,upon Burmah Shell Oil Storage and Dist. Co. v. Manmad Municipality  1 .

arguments.claim: Municipality prepared to grant refund on goods actually sent outside octroi limits on proof thereof, subject to rules

anchor.surface_text: Even before the High Court the learned Advocate appearing for the Municipality stated that if any goods belonging to the company were actually sent outside the octroi limits the Municipality was prepared to grant refund on proof thereof, That is the stand of the Municipality even to-day.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cidence or rate were number altered. In our opinion, the companypany was liable to pay octroi tax on goods brought into local area,  a  to be companys

arguments.court_reasoning: Company not liable for re-exported goods but must follow refund procedure.

arguments.claim: Company liable to pay octroi only on first category (goods consumed by itself); not on others

anchor.surface_text: The Company claimed in the High Court that it was not liable to pay octroi on categories other than the first. This claim was rejected but the Municipality agreed to give a refund according to rules- in respect of the fourth category.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ea that the tax companyld number legitimately be levied and in this case the municipality has agreed to refund the amount of tax on goods re-exported

arguments.court_reasoning: Liable on second and third categories as goods brought for consumption/use/sale therein.

arguments.claim: Octroi payable on goods brought into local area for consumption by itself or sold to consumers direct or to dealers who sell to consumers within area, irrespective of where consumers use them

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the company was liable to pay octroi tax on goods brought into local area,  a  to be consumed by itself or sold by it to consumers direct and  b  for sale to dealers who in their turn sold the goods to consumers within the municipal area irrespective of whether such consumers bought them for use in the area or outside it.

arguments.claim: No need to follow procedure for imposing new tax post-1954 amendment as tax remained the same

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter it was not necessary for the Municipality to follow the procedure for imposing taxes when the section was amended. The tax still remained the same. Its nature, incidence or rate were not altered.

arguments.claim: Prior to amendment, sale was implicit in 'consumption or use' if goods destined for consumption/use by purchaser within area

anchor.surface_text: In other words, a sale of the goods brought inside, even though not expressly mentioned in the description of octroi as it stood formerly, was implicit, provided the goods were not re-exported out of the area but were bought inside for use or consumption by buyers inside the area.

arguments.claim: Consumption not limited to act by importer but includes distribution to consumers within area (citing State of Bombay v United Motors)

anchor.surface_text: The expression for the purpose of consumption in that State must, in our opinion, be understood as having reference not merely to the individual importer or purchaser but as contemplating distribution eventually to consumers in general within the State.

holdings.text: It was not necessary for the Municipality to follow the procedure for imposing taxes when section 73(iv) was amended in 1954 as the tax remained the same and its nature, incidence or rate were not altered.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter it was not necessary for the Municipality to follow the procedure for imposing taxes when the section was amended. The tax still remained the same. Its nature, incidence or rate were not altered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1954 amendment adding 'sale' did not introduce new tax but clarified existing scope of octroi on goods for consumption or use therein; no change in tax character requiring reframing of rules under ss. 58(j), 60, 75, 76.

holdings.text: Prior to 1954 amendment, octroi under section 73(iv) was payable on goods brought for sale if destined for consumption or use by purchasers within the octroi limits, as 'sale' was implicit in 'consumption or use'.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, a sale of the goods brought inside, even though not expressly mentioned in the description of octroi as it stood formerly, was implicit, provided the goods were not re-exported out of the area but were bought inside for use or consumption by buyers inside the area.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical understanding of octroi, legislative practice, constitutional entries, and conduct of taxpayers confirm 'consumption or use' encompassed goods entering for eventual consumption/use by others via sale within area.

holdings.text: Octroi is payable on goods brought into octroi limits and sold by the company to dealers or consumers within the limits but consumed outside (third category), irrespective of where ultimate consumers use them.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the companypany was liable to pay octroi tax on goods brought into local area,  a  to be companysumed by itself or sold by it to companysumers direct and  b  for sale to dealers who in their turn sold the goods to companysumers within the municipal area irrespective of whether such companysumers bought them for use in the area or outside it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Taxable event is entry of goods meant to reach ultimate user/consumer in area; sale within area puts goods 'in the way of' consumption/use therein, even if later removed.

holdings.text: Company not liable to octroi on goods brought into limits and re-exported (fourth category), but must follow procedure in rules for refund.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany was, however, number liable to octroi in respect of goods which it brought into the local area and which were re-exported. But to enable the companypany to save itself from tax in that case it had to follow the procedure laid down by rules for refund of taxes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Octroi leviable only on goods retained for consumption/use/sale therein; re-export exempts via refund mechanism under existing rules/by-laws.

holdings.text: 'Consumption' under octroi includes distribution to ultimate consumers within the area, not limited to importer's own act.

anchor.surface_text: The expression for the purpose of consumption in that State must, in our opinion, be understood as having reference not merely to the individual importer or purchaser but as contemplating distribution eventually to consumers in general within the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following State of Bombay v. United Motors, consumption contemplates chain to general consumers; supported by Article 286 explanation.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons above stated this appeal must fail.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed upholding the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition; Company liable to pay octroi on goods in categories 2 and 3 (sold within limits whether consumed inside or outside); refund available for category 4 (re-exported goods) as per rules.
directions: Company to follow rules for refund of octroi on re-exported goods
